Saturday, July 22.speaker: Rhiju Das
Saturday, July 22.affiliation: Principal Investigator, Eterna; Das Lab, Stanford University
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Introductory remarks from Eterna's principal investigator.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Seth Cooper; Scott Horowitz
Saturday, July 22.topic: Education in Foldit: Modes and dojos
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Foldit is a citizen science video game, but has been used extensively in education ranging from middle school to graduate school. Two recent additions to the game have made education with Foldit considerably easier than in the past, Foldit Education Mode, and the Dojo. In this presentation, we will provide an overview of these features and their use, and lessons that could be useful for other citizen science games.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Mark Vaughan, PhD
Saturday, July 22.topic: Using Eterna in a second-year biochemistry course to support work-integrated learning
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Work-integrated learning (WIL) is a form of experiential learning in which a student's academic studies are enhanced through work experiences in partnership with external organizations. Incorporating WIL into the chemistry and biochemistry curriculum can be challenging in lower-level courses due to the limited technical skills that students have at that stage of their education. This presentation focuses on an accessible WIL project in a second-year biochemistry course based on Eterna, and explores opportunities for expanding the scope in future offerings.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Catherine Eichhorn, PhD
Saturday, July 22.topic: Eterna in the classroom: Enhancing student understanding of RNA folding
Saturday, July 22.abstract: This talk will present a college level laboratory course focused on the fluorogenic Pepper RNA aptamer as a model system. To explore RNA design and ligand recognition, this discovery-based course integrates organic synthesis, molecular modeling, RNA synthesis, and high-throughput binding assays. Course design, implementation, and student outcomes will be discussed. This course meets an increasing need to train students in hypothesis generation, data interpretation, and cross-disciplinary approaches to tackle the biggest problems facing society.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Quentin Vicens
Saturday, July 22.abstract: RNA is often portrayed as a wavy line or limp spaghetti. Yet, RNA folds up in space. RNA shapes may be quite elaborate, with many G-C and A-U base pairs. In this presentation, we will explore how the regions in between base pairs also interact with one another, enriching the pool of base pairs RNA can form. These regions often adopt specific three dimensional patterns that support RNA architectures.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Bret Lange, Riccardo Gil, Joseph D. Yesselman
Saturday, July 22.topic: Quantitative DMS measurements determine tertiary contact thermodynamics at nucleotide resolution
Saturday, July 22.abstract: For biological RNAs to fold into complex 3D structures they must fold long-range tertiary contacts. These contacts lock the 3D shape of an RNA into its functional form. Measuring the thermodynamic properties of these contacts has been challenging. Here we present a novel method that can measure the strength of the tetraloop/tetraloop receptor (TL/TLR) tertiary contact in a high-throughput manner using DMS chemical mapping.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Jeff Anderson-Lee (jandersonlee)
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Overview of ArcKnot/ArcPlot for puzzles, pseudoknots, and switches with demo if time permits.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Rhiju Das
Saturday, July 22.affiliation: Principal Investigator, Eterna; Das Lab, Stanford University
Saturday, July 22.abstract: The OpenKnot challenge seeks to discover new complex RNA folds both within Nature and from the imagination of Eterna players. Early rounds have completed, and I'll describe some initial solutions, how they were scored, and the potential impact in biology and medicine of the project.

Saturday, July 22.speaker: Jonathan Romano (LFP6)
Saturday, July 22.topic: A new intuition: Eterna gameplay beyond thermodynamics
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Puzzle solving on Eterna has historically revolved around thermodynamic models, predicting structures through minimum free energy calculation and exposing calculated nearest neighbor free energy values. However, newer modeling methods with higher accuracy have come into the picture which change fundamental assumptions and information players use when solving puzzles. What exactly is this change, how does it impact players, and how can it change the way we think about and visualize puzzles as we solve them?

Join the Eterna community for casual discussions in smaller breakout rooms. Please bring your ideas and questions!
  • Eterna Players Alliance (EPA)
  • Labs past, present, and future
  • Scripts and Eterna technology

Saturday, July 22.speaker: William Dunlap (Astromon)
Saturday, July 22.abstract: Join in our annual challenge to solve a puzzle specifically designed for Eternacon 9.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Victor Tse, PhD Candidate
Sunday, July 23.affiliation: UC Santa Cruz, Center for Molecular Biology of RNA
Sunday, July 23.topic: Designing RNA drugs for rare diseases
Sunday, July 23.abstract: The Sanford Lab has discovered antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) that rescue RNA splicing of multiple hemophilia A-linked variants of coagulation factor VIII (F8) exon 16 by targeting an inhibitory RNA structure. These ASOs:structure interactions increases the accessibility of the polypyrimidine tract and inhibits hnRNPA1-dependent splicing silencers. Together, this structure-function mechanism and its effect on RNA splicing provides a potential target for precision therapies for a subset of HA patients harboring specific F8 mutations.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Blanton S. Tolbert, PhD
Sunday, July 23.topic: Viral RNA structures: An opportunity for broad public engagement
Sunday, July 23.abstract: RNA Viruses persists to pose serious threats to human health and global economies. Disease progression mediated by viral pathogenesis requires numerous interactions between house proteins and viral RNA (vRNA) structures. Host-vRNA complexes drive essential processes in the replication cycle of viruses; as such, they represent untapped targets for therapeutic intervention.  In this talk, I will discuss research underway in my group that offers insights into fundamental viral RNA processes and that can be used to engage broader audiences.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Momodou B. Camara
Sunday, July 23.topic: Exploring the dance of RNA: Structural dynamics in 7SK RNA central domain
Sunday, July 23.abstract: The 7SK RNA is noncoding RNA found in cells that help to control gene expression. It does this by interacting with proteins to form a complex called 7SK ribonucleoprotein (RNP). This complex regulates transcription, essential for making proteins in our cells. This talk will focus on the structural dynamics we discovered in the central domain of the 7SK that has the potential to regulate its function.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Dina Buitrago; Karmen Williams; Ronald Lorenzo
Sunday, July 23.affiliation: City University of New York; Prairie View A&M University
Sunday, July 23.abstract: Earlier this year we conducted an Eterna player survey to learn about the Eterna community.  We want to know who you are and what motivates you to be active on Eterna.  Eterna last conducted a survey of this kind in 2015.  How has the player community changed in that time?  We will present your results and get your feedback!

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Jennifer Pearl
Sunday, July 23.topic: Serena FoldChange prediction algorithm and analysis walkthrough
Sunday, July 23.abstract: An introduction to the Serena RNA Switch FoldChange prediction algorithm that performs a detailed automated analysis of the ensemble and the gives a numerical value for the prediction fold change +/- 6 (based on training data) A walkthrough on how to use it to perform analysis of a switch as well will be given, and this will be a detailed analysis of a selection of the PNAS SSNG1 lab. Serena will answer questions around why the Eterna 30 and 60 score groups exists, where we have designs that on the surface look perfect but fail to perform. It is revealed that this is actually a factor of variation in the ensemble.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: William Dunlap (Astromon)
Sunday, July 23.abstract: Eterna player ASO designing methods and spreadsheets/tools to help in the process.

Sunday, July 23.speaker: Christian Choe, PhD Candidate
Sunday, July 23.topic: Rationally designed RNA sensors that compute functions of multiple inputs (OpenTB paper)
Sunday, July 23.abstract: Designing small single molecules that compute digital functions on the concentrations of input molecular partners represents a major unsolved challenge in molecular design. Using the crowdsourced RNA design platform Eterna, we demonstrate that high-throughput, iterative experimental testing of diverse RNA designs can solve increasingly complex conditional molecular sensing problems.
